ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: While I very much enjoyed this class, I think the material covered could have been a series of lectures rather than an entire class; and that the class could have been asked to engage with the material a bit more. Rather, we all sat back on our heels and listened to stories from the 60s through today. Leon and Tom are not the most direct and efficient lecturers, and their lectures could have been more structured. Additionally, I feel like the course was often quite repetitive. If this course were to be offered again, I would suggest it be entirely focused on case law; or that it really look deeply at today's political system and discuss legitimate pathways to improvement.

This class often felt as though it lacked structure and organization, but the topics covered were still incredibly important and beneficial to those of us interested in U.S. policy. If you can hang in there with an unstructured lecture-based seminar, it's worth it.

I really cherish my opportunity to be able to attend this class under Leon and Thomas, the writers of the Clean Air Act and Clean Water Act. I feel that in a way the baton of responsibility to protect the environment and the wellfare of people has been passed down from them to us. I feel incredibly honored to take this class and to converse with them. I have tried my best to engage in class and to deliver my final presentation and paper, though the amount of information I have learned is only the tip of the iceberg to the vast and rich sea of knowledge and stories that will take my life time to discover. I am very satisfied with this class. I believe more than a class, Leon and Thomas are serving as models of inspiration for me and my peers.

I think that this was a very good course, although it perhaps could have been shorter. I felt like we ran out of things to talk about towards the end. I also was very disappointed with the final written assignment. I thought that we were going to be able to choose our own paper topics, and was looking forward to that.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: They offered a practical guide of how policy is made, which is very valuable for folks who don't have experience in policy-making.
Leon and Tom are incredibly knowledgeable, from a personal perspective, about the CAA and CWA process and legislation. Their ability to remember actors and activities is incredible.

The unbelievable wealth of knowledge and experience that Leon and Tom have - nobody should pass up an opportunity to learn from people who have been in the trenches of environmental policy the way these two have.
See above.

The best aspect of the course is that the invaluable experience and knowledge of the instructors in the federal government and about the relevant environmental laws were made during the time that they worked on drafting those laws.
Having the opportunity to hear about the formation of the original U.S. environmental statutes.
The stories told by Leon and Tom were fascinating. I gained the most from some of their tangential stories and comments.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The course could have benefited from some additional structure--so that it was clear to students what was being covered in class.

Addressed this above, but the course needs direction; more material; a focus on the present; or a restructuring to provide a more in-depth exploration of case law (for a purpose) -- the course as is is worth, in my opinion, max 2 credits.

The wandering, anecdotal-heavy, and occasionally hard-to-follow flow of the course could probably be addressed with some time spent at the beginning of each class discussing a roadmap for that lecture and the main concepts that Tom and Leon wish students to grasp. Slightly more time devoted to discussion at the end of each class would also help with thus (but I caution this class from moving too far away from a lecture-style because I think that actually worked quite well).
Three hours was too long for this course.
Would have been good to have more purposeful discussion and Q&A sessions. Also was often difficult to follow lectures, discussion went many different directions at once.

I would have appreciated more structure to this class. I often felt like it was more story-time than a structured lesson about a particular topic. I could have used stronger wrap-ups as we moved through different topics, as well as framework within which these stories could be told.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There was no discussion section, but this is the first class I've ever taken where I would actually recommend the inclusion of a semi-weekly discussion section (or build in a more structured 30-minute discussion window into some of the classes).
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I didn't know much about the CAA and CWA before this course, and now I know them in some detail. This is important because they are landmark environmental legislation in the US. Otherwise, while the stories told were interesting, I'm not sure they shed much light on how to effect politics today; rather, they cast light on what is, in my mind, irreparably broken in our political system.

I know that my work will someday either take me to Capitol Hill or require me to work with folks there (either collaboratively or in an advocacy/lobbying capacity), and so understanding their perspectives (albeit from a slightly different period in American history) was very, very valuable.
It fits very well with my interests.

This course helped me learn about all of the underlying pieces that contribute to the passing of important environmental legislation, especially those pieces that might not be discussed in a more textbook based course. The course showed how legislation is passed through the first-hand knowledge of Leon and Tom, which was a unique experience.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took it because I hoped to learn about CAA and CWA; and because I hoped to investigate pathways by which someone could influence political decision making today.
I want to be inspired and I want to change the course of a nation's history the way my instructors did.
I want to learn about how the relevant environmental law was established.
Wanted to get some historical context for the creation of the CCA and CWA in the US.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I learned about legislation; we did not learn about pathways forward.
I didn't really know what to expect going into this class, but I'm happy with what I got out of it.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.

Yes and no. The things are learned were unexpected, and I did not necessarily learn what I expected to. This was largely due to the course being a bit less structured than I expected. But I was surprised by some of the experiences that were discussed by Leon and Tom, which led to many more "lessons learned" than I expected.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This was a fun class, and gave great insight into the major, formative environmental legislation in the U.S. The discussions and lectures were a bit unfocused, especially for a full 3 hours, but the stories were excellent and I find myself gaining more and more insights from the class as I reflect back on it. Leon and Tom are incredibly accomplished and it was an honor to get to learn from their experience.
If you are remotely interested in government, policy, or environmental law in the United States, take it. If those three things don't sound interesting, you probably won't enjoy the class.
Ask questions!!
Be willing to ask direct questions to clarify what is being talked about.
Take it, no excuses!
